quotes.quote: Men go shopping just as men go out fishing or hunting, to see how large a fish may be caught with the smallest hook.
The odds of going to the store for a loaf of bread and coming out with only a loaf of bread are three billion to one.
Recreational shopping is the shortest distance between two points: you and broke.
Shopping is a woman thing. It's a contact sport like football. Women enjoy the scrimmage, the noisy crowds, the danger of being trampled to death, and the ecstasy of the purchase.
A bargain is something you can't use at a price you can't resist.
A bargain ain't a bargain unless it's something you need.
I rationalize shopping. I buy a dress because I need change for gum.
I love vintage shopping, I think it's really fun. And I love the feeling of finding the most amazing piece for less.
I could lie and pretend that I hunt and camp, but that wouldn't be me. Clothes? Shopping? That's stuff I like!
The quickest way to know a woman is to go shopping with her.
I went to a general store but they wouldn't let me buy anything specific.
Whoever said money can't buy happiness simply didn't know where to go shopping.
I don't shop because I need something, I just shop for shopping's sake.
Buy, buy, says the sign in the shop window; Why, why, says the junk in the yard.
Women usually love what they buy, yet hate two-thirds of what is in their closets.
I've been shopping all my life and still have nothing to wear.
I love shopping. There is a little bit of magic found in buying something new. It is instant gratification, a quick fix.
I will go out of my way to avoid the shopping crowds and the extreme consumerism - I hate all that.
It's time to shop high heels if your fiance kisses you on the forehead.
I bought two items to get a third free, and then I returned the two. I should be Shopper of the Year.
If men liked shopping, they'd call it research.

On the one hand, shopping is dependable: You can do it alone, if you lose your heart to something that is wrong for you, you can return it; it's instant gratification and yet something you buy may well last for years.
I always say shopping is cheaper than a psychiatrist.
I like my money right where I can see it: hanging in my closet.
It's crowded, which pleases me. Salesladies intimidate me, I don't like to be caught shopping.
The secret idea she was forming of an afterlife gave her the foothold she needed to endure the agonies to come, a newfound courage and optimism which found instant expression through shopping.
Shopping at any level is a bit of therapy for my medulla oblongata.
For some, shopping is an art; for others, it's a sport. It can be a vice and it can be a cause. Some love it. Some hate it. Rarely is someone indifferent.
Too many people spend money they haven't earned, to buy things they don't want, to impress people they don't like.
When I shop, the world gets better, and the world is better, but then it's not, and I need to do it again.
